I think it sounds good, but I'd raise a few potential concerns.  For 
one thing, it's a linearly told story: you go here, you go there, you 
do this, you do that.  What made the built-in campaign (BIC) for 
Gladiator so fun, though, was the sense of exploration: which is the 
best path to take?  Do I need to level up a bit before I can clear 
this area?

The BIC still had an overarching narrative: hunt-down and kill 
Jakarta.  Within this, you had several sub-plots: Carl the Druid and 
the evil magic-users, the undead fighting the slimes, Cenweith Manor, 
etc.  Each one of these plots was linear (more or less), so you still 
got some story told.

So my first beef would be the linearity issue.  The second is that a 
lot of the levels have premises that may come off strangely: one 
third of your army has turned -- presumably this doesn't mean your 
squad (since you can't actually steal people from the squad), but if 
it means simply your NPC forces, then the level will probably wind up 
being pretty easy (2/3 of your forces + you vs. 1/3).

Generally, I think NPCs only work as cannon fodder -- or so it seemed 
playing the BIC.

- Mark
